bibl.title: Letter from William H. Welch to Mabel H. Lazear, April 4, 1908

div1.p: Welch sends Mabel Lazear a check from Phipps. Welch hopes that the pension increase will pass the House.

div1.head: Letter from William H. Welch to Mabel H. Lazear, April 4, 1908
div1.p:
When Mr. Henry Phipps, who established
the 'Phipps Dispensary' for tuberculosis connected with
the Johns Hopkins Hospital, was here for a few hours
last Sunday, he was much interested in the tablet
to Dr. Lazear in the hospital. He knew about Dr.
Lazear's work and career, and I understood him to say
that he had known his father and mother. He
made some inquiries, and since his return to New
York he has sent me the enclosed letter (which
you need not return) and the cheque, which I have
endorsed and also enclose.

In speaking with Dr. Thayer about Mr. Phipps's
gift, he intimated that you might feel some
hesitation in accepting it. I hope that you
will accept it for the purpose indicated by Mr.
Phipps, and I am rather inclined to appeal
personally
personally to you to do so for the sake of the children and for Mr. Phipps.
The gift was not solicited or suggested by me or any
one else, but is entirely Mr. Phipps's own generous
thought, and I know that it must be a pleasure
and satisfaction to him to give it. Perhaps
Mr. Phipps's acquaintance with Dr. Lazear's family
may be an additional reason for accepting the
gift. I have a high regard for Mr. Phipps
as an upright, kind hearted man, who has
made generous contributions for many public
purposes, especially in the fight against tuber-
culosis.

I need not assure you of the warm interest which
I have in you and your family. It will be
shameful if the bill to increase your pension does
not pass the house. I apprehend that the
main obstacle may be Mr. Loudens l lager. He
opposed the pension for Mrs. Reed, and it was
almost an accientaccident that the bill passed in spite
of his opposition. I think that you can count
upon every effort being made to secure the passage
of the bill through the house. There is no difficulty
in the Senate.

Will you kindly acknowledge to Mr. Phipps
the receipt of the cheque.

With the kindest regards and all good
wishes for yourself and your children, I am,
div1.closer:
Very Sincerely Yours, William H. Welch.
P. S. It is possible that Mr. Phipps may be of assistance
in securing the passage of the pension bill. At any rate
I am writing to him about it.
W.H.W.
